title: Racist woman calls nurse treating her brother in A&E a ‘black b***h’
text:
Jemma Barrett faces up to six months in prison (Picture: Cavendish Press)

A woman is facing jail after hurling racist abuse at a black nurse who was helping her brother in a busy A&E department.

Jemma Barrett, 32, called Helen Amanuael a ‘black b***h’ in a heated exchange at 4am, after a boozy night out in Manchester’s Gay Village.

She demanded doctors immediately rush to her brother, who had been left with head injuries after being beaten up in a nightclub.

Getting nose-to-nose with the nurse, Barrett shouted: ‘Why the f**k has he not been seen? Can you not see he has been injured?

‘Don’t tell me to calm down. I’m not going to calm down. Your breath stinks. Who do you think you are? I will find out where you live and come for you.’

She says she called nurse Helen Amanuel a ‘daft b***h’ rather than a ‘black b***h’ (Picture: Cavendish Press)

Security staff at Manchester Royal Infirmary ejected Barret who was then arrested outside.

Advertisement

She was convicted of a racially aggravated public order offence following a trial at the city’s magistrates’ court.

Barrett, of Broughton, Salford, who denied wrongdoing, faces up to six months in jail when she is sentenced later this month.

Recalling the incident on June 24, Ms Amanuel says her team sat the defendant’s brother in a chair in the corner because the beds were full of patients.

Barrett, who had been celebrating her birthday, stormed over and asked why doctors had not seen to her brother yet.

She got up in the nurse’s face and said she would ‘find out where she lives’ (Picture: Cavendish Press)

She said a group of men had left him with a crack on the back of his skull and a wound on his forehead.

Ms Amanuel said: ‘I explained can you calm down, we have other patients that are poorly, but she got very upset.’

The nurse of eight years said she took his medical history and decided it was safe for him to sit and wait.

Ms Amanuel added: ‘She was waving her arms around and shouting the whole time – there were 15 other people in that room.’

After being told security would have to be called in, Barrett said: ‘Who do you think you are? He is just sat in a chair, nobody is seeing him.’

The court heard how Barrett squared up with Ms Amanuel so closely they were almost touching, before threatening to ‘find out where she lives’.

The nurse said: ‘I was upset because I was trying to help her brother.

She told the nurse who was looking after her injured brother that her ‘breath stinks’ (Picture: Cavendish Press)

‘This is a place where I work, I come to feel safe and help people, there was no need for that approach.

Advertisement

Advertisement

A colleague had put herself in between the pair as security were called to remove Barrett.

Ms Amanuel said: ‘She turned around and called me a black b***h loud enough for everyone in the room to hear.’

She says staff at A&E regularly take abuse from unruly patients and relatives, with some getting punched and spat at.

Barrett told the court she only raised her voice ‘because she was scared’ and denied calling the nurse a ‘black b***h’ or saying her ‘breath stinks’.

She added: ‘That is not something that would come out of my mouth.

‘I have got black nephews and nieces I wouldn’t say something like that.

‘I shouted daft b***h, those other words did not come out of my mouth they never have and never will, I’ve lived around black people all my life I’m not a racist person.’

She says her only priority was caring for her brother, who had been waiting for nearly 30 minutes and was covered in blood.

Barrett said she was nervous because her sister suffered a miscarriage after being left by emergency staff for seven hours following a major car crash.

She added: ‘If I was waving my arms around I was just saying check on my brother.

‘It would have been normal for me to react like that if my brother is slumped in a chair like that and bleeding.

Advertisement

‘Maybe I would have been swearing and things but I wasn’t shouting all the way through.’

‘I was worried and I was panicking I stepped out of line for a couple of minutes in the hospital and that is it.’

Nicola Durham, prosecuting, said: ‘The defendant turned up in a drunk, emotional state demanding attention and not getting her own way and despite the upsetting circumstances the nurse was just trying to do her job.’

description: A Manchester Royal Infirmary nurse was targeted with racial abuse by the sister of a man she was trying to look after.
